code: ### Optionally: specify GitHub Personal Access Token (GITHUB_PAT) ### See here why this might be important for you: ### https://kwb-r.github.io/kwb.pkgbuild/articles/install.html#set-your-github_pat  # Sys.setenv(GITHUB_PAT = "mysecret_access_token")  # Install package "remotes" from CRAN if (! require("remotes")) {   install.packages("remotes", repos = "https://cloud.r-project.org") }  # Install KWB package 'kwb.pkgstatus' from GitHub remotes::install_github("KWB-R/kwb.pkgstatus")

title: Add a Grid if the First Argument is TRUE — addGridIfTrue
text: plot.grid logical. TRUE grid plotted, else . xPositions x positions vertical grid lines yPositions y positions horizontal grid lines col colour grid lines, passed abline lty line type grid lines, passed abline ... additional arguments passed abline

title: Add Labels — addLabels
text: add labels given x-positions plot (alternating y positions   avoid overlapping labels)

title: Add Labels — addLabels
code: addLabels(   x,   labels = as.character(x),   y0 = 0,   bandheight = 0.1,   col = "black",   group.size = 3,   alternating = FALSE,   col.line = "black",   lty = 1,   lty.horiz.line = 0,   adj = -0.1,   cex = 0.7 )

title: Add Labels — addLabels
text: x x positions labels labels vector character containing labels y0 base y position labels bandheight height band "around" (alternating == FALSE) (alternating == TRUE) y0 fraction plot region height (e.g. 0.1 10 percent). Default: 0.1 col colour labels group.size passed labelPositionY alternating passed labelPositionY col.line colour lines labels lty type lines labels (defined par) lty.horiz.line type horizontal line (defined par) adj passed text cex passed text

what: best nrow/ncol setting for n plots — bestRowColumnSetting
title: best nrow/ncol setting for n plots — bestRowColumnSetting
text: Number rows columns optimal plot grid n plots

title: best nrow/ncol setting for n plots — bestRowColumnSetting
code: bestRowColumnSetting(n, target.ratio = 1, device.ratio = NULL)

title: best nrow/ncol setting for n plots — bestRowColumnSetting
text: n number plots placed matrix equally sized plot cells target.ratio desired height/width ratio within plot (ignoring margins). Default: 1 device.ratio desired height/width ratio output device. Default: kwb.plot:::getPlotRegionRatio()

title: best nrow/ncol setting for n plots — bestRowColumnSetting
text: named vector two elements first element (nrow)   representing number rows second element (ncol)   representing number columns optimal plot grid used  n plots current plot region

title: best nrow/ncol setting for n plots — bestRowColumnSetting
code: # save current graphical parameter setting   old.par <- graphics::par(no.readonly = TRUE)      for (i in 2:5) {          graphics::par(mfrow = kwb.plot::bestRowColumnSetting(i))          for (j in 1:i) {       plot(seq_len(j), main = paste0("j = ", j, "/", i))     }         }         # restore graphical parameter setting   graphics::par(old.par)

title: Draw Boxplot Icon — drawBoxplot
text: draws symmetric boxplot icon around centre

title: Draw Boxplot Icon — drawBoxplot
text: centre.x x coordinate user coordinates around box drawn centre.y y coordinate user coordinates around box drawn boxwidth.cm width box cm. Default: 1 boxheight.cm height box cm. Default: boxwidth.cm whisker.cm length whiskers cm. Default: boxheight.cm

title: Draw Boxplot Icon — drawBoxplot
code: ### prepare a simple plot area   plot(1:5)      ### draw a box around the centre at (2, 2) with default proportions   drawBoxplot(2, 2, boxwidth.cm = 1)      ### draw a box around the centre at (3, 3) with differing width and height   drawBoxplot(3, 3, boxwidth.cm = 2, boxheight.cm = 1)      ### draw a box around the centre at (4, 4) with modified whisker lengths   drawBoxplot(4, 4, boxwidth.cm = 0.5, boxheight.cm = 1.5, whisker.cm = 0.5)

what: Create a generic barplot using ggplot. — generic_barplot
title: Create a generic barplot using ggplot. — generic_barplot
text: function generates barplot using ggplot, providing flexibility  customising plot according data. barplot can represent  different groups sub-groups, option calculate bar heights  based counts specific values.

title: Create a generic barplot using ggplot. — generic_barplot
code: generic_barplot(   data,   group_by,   values_in = NULL,   fill_by = NULL,   percentaged = FALSE )

title: Create a generic barplot using ggplot. — generic_barplot
text: data data frame containing data plotting. group_by name column `data` contains group  labels. unique value column corresponds distinct group,  bar generated group. column must type  character factor. values_in (Optional) name column `data` contains values used calculate bar heights. provided, bar heights calculated based counts, .e., number rows `data` belong group defined values column `group_by`. fill_by (Optional) name column `data` defines sub-groups. sub-group represented different fill colour, bars consist stacked, filled rectangles. parameter useful visualising sub-groups within group. percentaged set `TRUE`, bars stretched extend full height plot. option applicable `fill_by` specified bar represented stack rectangles filled different colour. heights rectangles reflect proportions sub-group (count sum corresponding rows values `values_in` column) within group. default value `FALSE`.

title: Create a generic barplot using ggplot. — generic_barplot
text: barplot visualising data using ggplot.

title: Create a generic barplot using ggplot. — generic_barplot
text: Note: description written help ChatGPT.

title: Create a generic barplot using ggplot. — generic_barplot
code: # Basic usage my_data <- data.frame(  group = c("A", "A", "A", "B", "B", "C", "C"),  value = c(10, 15, 3, 8, 12, 5, 20),  subgroup = c("X", "Y", "X", "X", "Y", "X", "Y") )  generic_barplot(   data = my_data,    group_by = "group",    values_in = "value",    fill_by = "subgroup" )   # Percentage-based bar heights generic_barplot(   data = my_data,    group_by = "group",    values_in = "value",    fill_by = "subgroup",    percentaged = TRUE )

code: labelPositionY(n, y0 = 0, bandheight = 0.1, group.size = 3, alternating = TRUE)

title: y-positions for labels — labelPositionY
text: n number y-positions generated y0 y-positions around generated values "alternate" bandheight height band "around" (alternating == FALSE) (alternating == TRUE) y0 fraction plot region height (e.g. 0.1 10 percent). Default: 0.1 group.size number labels placed "group" label positions modified along y axis alternating TRUE (default) label positions  alternating positive negative values

what: barplot with more flexibility on labels and axis — mybarplot
title: barplot with more flexibility on labels and axis — mybarplot
text: barplot function allowing set label axis arguments, e.g. rotation   labels, giving unit axis values

title: barplot with more flexibility on labels and axis — mybarplot
code: mybarplot(   height,   names.arg = NULL,   cex.axis = graphics::par("cex.axis"),   cex.names = graphics::par("cex.axis"),   ...,   args.text = NULL,   args.yaxis = NULL )

title: barplot with more flexibility on labels and axis — mybarplot
text: height barplot names.arg barplot cex.axis character expansion factor axis labels cex.names character expansion factor bar group labels ... additional arguments barplot args.text list arguments given text called plot bar group labels. Use args_text create list. args.yaxis list arguments given axis called plot y axis. Use args_yaxis create list.

title: barplot with more flexibility on labels and axis — mybarplot
text: Returns (invisibly) barplot returns: x positions   bars plotted

title: barplot with more flexibility on labels and axis — mybarplot
code: height1 <- structure(1:10, names = paste("Category", 1:10))      height2 <- matrix(     1:12, nrow = 3, dimnames = list(       c("A", "B", "C"), paste("Long cateogry name", 1:4))   )      graphics::par(mfrow = c(1, 2))      # In the simplest form, mybarplot does what barplot does...   x1 <- graphics::barplot(height1, main = "barplot")   x2 <- mybarplot(height1, main = "mybarplot")       # ... and gives the same result   identical(x1, x2) #> [1] TRUE      # We cannot distinguish the labels. With mybarplot we have finer access to the   # labels, such as rotation, yposition and adjustment     graphics::par(mfrow = c(1, 3))      graphics::barplot(height1, las = 2, main = "barplot")        mybarplot(height1, las = 2, main = "mybarplot",              args.text = args_text(srt = 45, y.abs = -1, col = "blue"))      mybarplot(height1, las = 2, main = "mybarplot",              args.text = args_text(srt = 90, y.abs = 10, col = "red"))       # Concerning the y-axis, you may e.g. give a unit to the values or modify the   # positions at which to draw ticks   graphics::par(mfrow = c(1, 1))      mybarplot(height1, las = 2, cex.names = 0.8,,             args.text = args_text(srt = 90, y.abs = -0.5),              args.yaxis = args_yaxis(at = 0:10, unit = " %", col.axis = "blue"))       graphics::par(mfrow = c(1, 2))      graphics::barplot(height2, main = "barplot", cex.names = 0.8)      mybarplot(height2, main = "mybarplot", cex.names = 0.8,              args.text = args_text(srt = 30))       graphics::barplot(height2, las = 1, main = "barplot",   beside = TRUE,                      cex.names = 0.8)      mybarplot(height2, las = 1, main = "mybarplot", beside = TRUE,              cex.names = 0.8, args.text = args_text(srt = 30))

title: Nice Labels — niceLabels
text: Generates nice vector labels suppressing labels certain   positions. labelStep given, every labelStep-th    label considered. vector labpos label positions   minimum distance mindist labels given, guaranteed   distance labels shown least mindist.

title: Nice Labels — niceLabels
code: niceLabels(label, labelstep = NULL, labelpos = NULL, mindist = 1, offset = 0)

title: Nice Labels — niceLabels
text: label vector labels labelstep step width labels printed, e.g. labelStep = 2 used plotting every second label. labelpos label positions mindist minimum distance labels offset offset index first remaining label (default: 1)  shifted. Default: 0, .e. labels indices 1, 1 +  1*labelstep, 1 + 2*labelstep, etc. remain. Offset = 1: labels  indices 2, 2 + 1*labelstep, 2 + 2*labelstep, etc. remain.

title: Nice Labels — niceLabels
code: x <- matrix(1:12, nrow = 3)      names.arg <- rep(1:4, each = 3)      mybarplot <- function(x, ...) {     barplot(x, horiz = TRUE, las = 1, beside = TRUE, ...)   }        mybarplot(x, names.arg = names.arg)    mybarplot(x, names.arg = niceLabels(names.arg, labelstep = 3))    mybarplot(x, names.arg = niceLabels(names.arg, labelstep = 3, offset = 1))    mybarplot(x, names.arg = niceLabels(names.arg, labelstep = 3, offset = 2))

what: Redirect Output of Plot Function to PNG file — output_to_png
title: Redirect Output of Plot Function to PNG file — output_to_png
text: Redirect output plot function PNG file

title: Redirect Output of Plot Function to PNG file — output_to_png
code: output_to_png(   FUN,   args,   filename,   size = unlist(kwb.utils::DIN.A4()),   units = "cm",   res = 300,   ...,   dbg = TRUE )

title: Redirect Output of Plot Function to PNG file — output_to_png
text: FUN plot function called args list arguments given plot function FUN filename full path PNG file written. extension ".png"  automatically appended omitted size vector containing width (first element) height (second element) plot, passed png. default  dimensions DIN A4 page used. units units passed png res resolution passed png ... arguments passed png dbg TRUE message "Plotting <filename>..." shown

title: Plot Frequencies of Level Combinations — plotLevelFrequencies
code: plotLevelFrequencies(data, vars_1 = NULL, vars_2 = NULL, relative = TRUE)

title: Plot Frequencies of Level Combinations — plotLevelFrequencies
text: data data frame vars_1 first vector column names vars_2 second vector column names relative TRUE (default)

title: Plot Frequencies of Level Combinations — plotLevelFrequencies
text: list objects class "ggplot"

title: Plot Frequencies of Level Combinations — plotLevelFrequencies
code: data <- data.frame(   fruit = c("apple", "cherry", "apple", "banana", "cherry"),   colour = c("green", "red", "red", "yellow", "green"),   size = c("small", "small", "big", "small", "big") )  plotLevelFrequencies(data) #> named list()

what: Plot Rain Data as Bars — plotRain
title: Plot Rain Data as Bars — plotRain
text: Plot Rain Data Bars

title: Plot Rain Data as Bars — plotRain
code: plotRain(   timestamps,   values,   gaugeName = "",   xlim = NULL,   ylim = NULL,   signal.width = NA,   shift.to.begin = 0,   col = "blue",   pch = 16,   reverse.ylim = TRUE,   las = 1,   innerMargins = c(0, 0, 0, 0),   add.time.axis = TRUE,   ... )

title: Plot Rain Data as Bars — plotRain
text: timestamps timestamps values precipitation values mm gaugeName Name rain gauge appear y label xlim x limits ylim y limits signal.width width time intervals represented timestamps, seconds. NA  (default) value deduced time differences  timestamps shift..begin value seconds timstamps need shifted order get begin time intervals timestamps represent. Default: 0 (meaning timestamps represent beginnings time  intervals). value signal.width mean timestamps represent ends time intervals value  signal.width/2 mean timestamps represent  midpoints time intervals represent. col fill colour bars. Default: "blue" pch plot character used plotting data points (given timestamps), additionally plotting bars. Set NA order suppress plotting points reverse.ylim TRUE (default), y axis reversed, .e. bars heading top bottom las numeric 0,1,2,3; style axis labels. See help par. innerMargins passed plot_variable add.time.axis passed plot_variable ... arguments passed points

title: Plot Filled Area Below a Curve Line — plot_curve_area
code: x <- seq(-pi, pi, pi/8)   y <- sin(x)      plot(x, y)   plot_curve_area(x, y, 0, col = "red")       plot(x, y)   plot_curve_area(x, y, -1, col = "red")   plot_curve_area(x, y, 1, col = "green")

what: Plot Filled Areas below Curve Lines using ggplot — plot_curve_areas_gg
title: Plot Filled Areas below Curve Lines using ggplot — plot_curve_areas_gg
text: Plot Filled Areas Curve Lines using ggplot

title: Plot Filled Areas below Curve Lines using ggplot — plot_curve_areas_gg
code: plot_curve_areas_gg(   x = seq_along(y_list[[1]]),   y_list,   col = NULL,   stack = FALSE,   legend = TRUE,   line_colour = "black" )

title: Plot Filled Areas below Curve Lines using ggplot — plot_curve_areas_gg
text: x x positions curve given y_list y_list list vectors y positions must long x col vector length y_list giving colours areas filled stack TRUE (default FALSE) areas stacked top otherwise overlayed. legend TRUE (default) standard legend shown, else  hidden line_colour colour curve lines

title: Plot Filled Areas below Curve Lines using ggplot — plot_curve_areas_gg
code: x <- 1:10  y_list <- list(rep(10, 10), 10*sin(x/pi), 5*cos(x/pi))  # Basic plot  plot_curve_areas_gg(x, y_list)    # Set the colours (must be as many as vectors in y_list) plot_curve_areas_gg(x, y_list, col = c("black", "white", "red"))   # Hide the legend plot_curve_areas_gg(x, y_list, legend = FALSE) #> Warning: The `<scale>` argument of `guides()` cannot be `FALSE`. Use "none" instead as #> of ggplot2 3.3.4. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the kwb.plot package. #>   Please report the issue at <https://github.com/kwb-r/kwb.plot/issues>.   # Stack the values instead of overlaying them plot_curve_areas_gg(x, y_list, stack = TRUE)

title: Plot a Variable of a Data Frame — plot_variable
code: plot_variable(   hydraulicData,   variableName = names(hydraulicData)[[2]],   type = .defaultPlotParameter("type", variableName),   col = .defaultPlotParameter("col", variableName),   ylab = .defaultPlotParameter("ylab", variableName),   pch = .defaultPlotParameter("pch", variableName),   xlim = NULL,   ylim = NULL,   add = FALSE,   plot.grid = TRUE,   innerMargins = c(0, 0, 0, 0),   absolute = FALSE,   reverse.ylim = FALSE,   add.time.axis = TRUE,   time.axis.in.margins = FALSE,   ... )

title: Plot a Variable of a Data Frame — plot_variable
text: hydraulicData data frame least two columns. First column expected contain timestamps variableName default: name second column type plot type, passed points col colour, passed points ylab y label, passed plot pch plot character, passed points xlim x limits, passed plot ylim y limits, passed plot add TRUE points added existing plot plot.grid TRUE grid drawn innerMargins margins (bottom, left, top, right) within plot area absolute TRUE, innerMargins interpreted absolute values instead  fractions plot region. Default: FALSE reverse.ylim TRUE (default), y axis reversed, .e. bars heading top bottom add.time.axis TRUE time axis drawn time.axis..margins TRUE time axis drawn within plot area excluding margins ... additional arguments passed plot

what: Set the Labels in a List of ggplot Objects — set_labels
title: Set the Labels in a List of ggplot Objects — set_labels
text: Set Labels List ggplot Objects

title: Set the Labels in a List of ggplot Objects — set_labels
code: set_labels(   plots,   ...,   indices = seq_along(plots),   label_data = NULL,   action = c("replace", "append", "prepend")[1],   sep = " " )

title: Set the Labels in a List of ggplot Objects — set_labels
text: plots list ggplot objects returned ggplot ... name-value pairs given labs. Possible names e.g. "x", "title", "subtitle", "caption". values vectors character recycled length indices. used labels given plot plots selected indices. indices indices plots label given. default label given plots label_data data frame containing different label types  different columns. given NULL arguments ...  ignored. action one "replace" (replace existing label),  "append" (append existing label), "prepend" (prepend existing label). sep separator used append one  "append", "prepend".

title: Set the Labels in a List of ggplot Objects — set_labels
code: p <- example_plot_2()  plots <- list(p, p, p, p)  plots_1 <- set_labels(   plots, title = c("Title A", "Title B", "Title C", "Title D"),   subtitle = "same subtitle", x = c("x label one", "x label two") )  plots_2 <- set_labels(   plots, title = c("(A)", "(B)", "(C)", "(D)"),   subtitle = "(always the same)", x = c("(one)", "(two)"),   action = "append" )  label_data <- data.frame(title = "Titles set with label_data",   subtitle = sprintf("Plot %d", seq_along(plots)) ) plots_3 <- set_labels(plots, label_data = label_data)  do.call(gridExtra::grid.arrange, plots_1)  do.call(gridExtra::grid.arrange, plots_2)  do.call(gridExtra::grid.arrange, plots_3)
